newsitem.title: USA: Software piracy on the rise, industry groups say.
newsitem.headline: Software piracy on the rise, industry groups say.

text.p: Nearly half of the new business computer software applications used around the world last year were pirated, industry trade groups said Wednesday.

A study released by the Business Software Alliance and the Software Publishers Association estimated that of about 523 million new business software programmes used around the world in 1996, 225 million were pirated copies.

That represented a 20 percent increase over 1995, the trade groups said. The study estimated a loss to software companies of about $11.2 billion last year from piracy. That was down from $13.3 billion in 1995, but the decrease was due to falling software prices, the groups said.
"The 1996 numbers show software piracy remains a significant global problem," said Ken Wasch, president of SPA.

The study showed that piracy in Eastern Europe is a major problem, with an average 80 percent of applications being pirated versions. About 91 percent of software in Russia is pirated, the study said.
The piracy rate in China was 96 percent last year, down from 97 percent the year before, the study said.
